awd_titl_txt: FET: Medium: Collaborative Research: An Efficient Framework for the Stochastic Verification of Computation and Communication Systems Using Emerging Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
Synthetic biology and nanotechnology place increasing demands on design methodologies to ensure dependable and robust operation. Consisting of noisy and unreliable components, these complex systems have large and often infinite state spaces that include extremely rare error states. Stochastic model checking techniques have demonstrated significant potential in quantitatively analyzing such system models under extremely low probability. Unfortunately, they generally require enumerating the model's state space, which is computationally intractable or impossible. Therefore, addressing these design challenges in emerging technologies requires enhancing the applicability of stochastic model checking. Motivated by this problem, this project investigates an automated stochastic verification framework that integrates approximate stochastic model checking and counterexample-guided rare-event simulation to improve the analysis accuracy and efficiency.  


This project focuses on verifying infinite-state continuous-time Markov chain models with rare-event properties. It addresses the scalability problem by first applying property-guided and on-the-fly state truncation techniques to prune unlikely states to obtain finite state representations that are amenable to stochastic model checking. In the case of false or indeterminate verification results, stochastic counterexamples are generated and utilized to improve the accuracy of the state reductions. Furthermore, it mines these critical counterexamples as automated guidance to improve the quality and efficiency for rare-event stochastic simulations. This verification framework will be integrated within existing state-of-the-art stochastic model checking tools, and benchmarked on a wide range of real-world case studies in synthetic biology and nanotechnology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

Our research focuses on advancing probabilistic model checking (PMC), a method that helps engineers evaluate system reliability and safety. This is particularly crucial for safety-critical systems like medical devices and synthetic biology applications. However, real-world systems often have vast, even infinite, state spaces, making traditional verification methods impractical.

A major goal of our work is improving computational efficiency of verification of practical safety-critical systems.  To address this, we developed the STAMINA software tool, which enables efficient verification by truncating the potentially infinite-state space enabling probabilistic model checking. We also created the RAGTIMER software tool to quickly compute probabilities of key system behaviors. Finally, we developed Wayfarer, a tool that targets scalable reachability analysis of biochemical reaction network models. To better diagnose system failures in large system models, we developed optimized counterexample generation methods for probabilistic models.  Since these failures can often be extremely rare, we explored alternative methods based on  importance sampling of Markov models, and we implemented our method in the software tool ASTERISM. Finally, our research has provided insights into the differences between model checking and stochastic simulation, helping practitioners select the best method for their needs. 

Many of our case studies in our research project focussed on synthetic biology, which has potential applications in medicine, energy, and environmental sciences. However, designing reliable genetic circuits is challenging due to high levels of random noise. Our methods help quantify the likelihood of errors—such as unintended drug release—leading to safer, more predictable designs.

Broader Impacts: Education & Outreach

Beyond technical contributions, we engaged in multiple education and outreach efforts to broaden participation in computing and engineering:

  • Hardware Foundation for a Smart World Workshop (January 2022, University of South Florida): this workshop introduced new college students to embedded system design without requiring prior experience in hardware or programming. 

  • Workshop on Digital Preservation & Trustworthy Computing (August 2022, Utah State University): Topics included digital archiving, logic circuits, and electronic voting security.

  • "Fun with Embedded System Design" Workshop (August 2023, University of South Florida): This event introduced participants to embedded systems through hands-on labs and a design competition. 

  • Synthetic Biology Workshop (June 2024, CU Boulder): A two-day event introduced a broad group of students to genetic circuit design through hands-on lab activities, including programming a liquid-handling robot. Several participants expressed interest in continuing their studies in this field.

  • Genetic Circuits Online Course: Released a three-course specialization on engineering genetic circuits on Coursera, which emphasizes interdisciplinary collaboration between engineers and biologists.

These efforts contribute to making STEM fields more accessible while fostering innovation in probabilistic verification and synthetic biology.
